JSX

  • react supports multiple platforms, e.g. native, web, etc
  • react dom is the code to interact with web browsers
  • react is the common piece of code which works across platforms, which is what we mostly use
  • we can write code using react apis using apis as follows - 
    const element = React.createElement("div", {
  className: "container",
  children: "Hello World",
});

const rootElement = document.getElementById("root");
ReactDOM.createRoot(rootElement).render(element);
  • jsx is much more friendly to work with 
    const element = <div className="container">Hello World</div>;
// render logic
  • but, since jsx isn’t js, it needs to be compiled to js. this is done by babel. also, since babel itself is written in js, we can also run babel in the browser during development to convert jsx to js on the fly
  • during production things are different because we would produce the minified build first
  • interpolation allows us to put js expressions in jsx using {}, e.g. <div children={children}>
  • for reusing jsx, we create components in react 
    const message = ({ children }) => {
  return <div className="message">{children}</div>
}

// usage
{
  message({ children: "Hello World" })
}
  • just like babel converts <div /> to React.createElement("div"), it can also convert <Function /> to React.createElement(Function) 
    <Message children="Hello World" />
  • note - if our function started with a lowercase, it would get the same treatment as a div i.e. React.createElement("message"), which is undesirable

Fragments

  • we can get complaints like jsx elements need a parent
  • use case - we want to render two jsx elements side by side without a parent element
  • in such cases, we can use fragments - 
    <React.Fragment>
  <Message children="Hello World" />
  <Message children="Goodbye World" />
</React.Fragment>
  • we can also use the shorthand <> in place of <React.Fragment>

Prop Types

  • this is a solution when not using typescript
  • we might want to validate the props passed to a component 
    Message.propTypes = {
  greeting: (props, propName, componentName) => {
    if (typeof props[propName] !== "string") {
      throw new Error("greeting should be of type string");
    }
  },
}
  • react runs these prop types in development only and not in production
  • we can use a library called prop-types as they have validators with a lot of functionality - 
    import PropTypes from "prop-types";

Message.propTypes = {
  greeting: PropTypes.string.isRequired,
};

Forms

  • react wraps the native events, by using synthetic events
  • the native events can be accessed via event.nativeEvent. however, we don’t have to, since working with synthetic events is almost the same as working with native events 
    function handleSubmit(event) {
  event.preventDefault();
  console.log(event.target.elements.username.value);
}

<form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
  <input name="username" />
  <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>
  • in the snippet above, the state of the input value is maintained by the dom
  • so, we query the dom to get the value of the input
  • we can make the component responsible for maintaining the state of the input by passing it the value and onChange props. here, we tell the dom the value to be shown inside the input 
    const [username, setUsername] = useState("");

function handleChange(event) {
  setUsername(event.target.value);
}
<input value={username} onChange={handleChange} />;

Key

  • when rendering a list of items, we should provide each item with a unique key
  • this is done for react to be able to easily compare the before and after lists, and update the dom properly
  • if we do not provide a key, react can get confused when we try to add / remove elements from the array and the rendered view can be different from what is expected
  • these keys only need to be unique across the same array, not all arrays
  • also, do not just use the array index by itself, as it is the default behavior and does not solve the problem
  • explanation - changing [apple, orange, grape] to [apple, grape] when using the index of the element as the key does not imply delete orange, it means delete grape and change orange to grape
  • another use case of key - we do not necessarily have to use keys in lists only. suppose, we want to fully rerender a child component. if the key prop which is passed to it changes, react re-instantiates the component

useState

  • used to maintain state in a component
  • it accepts the initial value, and returns an array, where the first argument is the current state and the second argument is a function to update the state
  • when we update the state using the second argument, it causes the entire function to rerender / rerun with useState returning the new value for the first argument
  • syntax - const [name, setName] = useState("");
  • another form of using setName - setName((name) => // logic to update name). use case - suppose the way we want to update the state relies on the previous state. we do not have to send the child component the name as props, just passing the setName function will do
  • another use case for the above - e.g. inside useEffect, we don’t to provide the state as a dependency to useEffect but the previous state does determine the value of the next state 
    useEffect(() => setCount((count) => count + 1), [
  // ... no need of providing count
]);
  • suppose the initial state relies on reading from the local storage. we could model it like this - 
    const [name, setName] = useState(localStorage.getItem("name") ?? "")
  • however, this way, every time the component re-renders, localStorage.getItem is rerun, despite the fact that it was used only once the first time to load the initial state of name
  • we can use lazy state initialization i.e. change useState(expensiveCOmputation()) to useState(expensiveComputation). this way, react calls it only the first time when it is needed 
    const [name, setName] = useState(() => localStorage.getItem("name") ?? "")
  • react batches state updates. so, in the following case, count might be incremented only by one - 
    const increment = () => {
  setCount(count + 1);
  setCount(count + 1);
  setCount(count + 1);
}
    this is because we reused the variable count maintained by useState even before it could get updated by the previous setCount. so, one solution is to use the alternate form of setCount - 
    const increment = () => {
  setCount((count) => count + 1);
  setCount((count) => count + 1);
  setCount((count) => count + 1);
}

useRef

  • ref is an object that stays consistent across re-renders of the component
  • it has a current property on it which can be updated to any value any time
  • when we use it with dom nodes, react automatically sets the ref’s current to the dom node once the dom node is rendered properly 
    const inputRef = useRef();

function handleSubmit(event) {
  event.preventDefault();
  console.log(inputRef.current.value);
}

<input ref={inputRef} name="username" />;
  • my understanding - because of the sequence in which events occur in react, the ref should be accessible in useEffect i.e. by the time the callback of useEffect is called for the first time, the rendering to browser and setting of ref would have happened
  • another use case of useRef - maintaining state updating which should not cause re-renders
  • a subtle observation - 
    useEffect(() => {
  // assume it sets a property called animator which has a destroy method
  // `destroy` cleans up all outstanding event listeners
  animate(divRef.current);
  return () => divRef.current.animator.destroy();
}, []);
    the above can be wrong, since divRef.current points to the latest div and not the div which was passed to animate by the time the cleanup function is called. so, the correct way - 
    useEffect(() => {
  const divNode = divRef.current;
  animate(divNode);
  return () => divNode.animator.destroy();
}, []);
  • useRef also accepts an initial value, e.g. useRef(5)

useEffect

  • used for side effects
  • useEffect accepts a callback which is run every time the component rerenders 
    React.useEffect(() => {
  localStorage.setItem("name", name);
});
  • it also accepts a second argument, the dependencies array. this way, the callback is only called the first time and every time one of the dependencies in the arrays change
  • note: useEffect does shallow comparison i.e. ===
  • so, if we put an object in the dependencies array, even if the value of none of the keys change, it might be treated as a new object by react - useEffect(cb, [{ key: "value" }])
  • optionally, the callback passed to useEffect can return a function which acts as a cleanup, which gets run every time the rerender is due to one of the dependencies passed to its useEffect or when the component is unmounted from the dom
  • because useEffect returns a cleanup function, do not make the callback passed to useEffect an async function, as that would implicitly imply that we return a promise, which react does not process

Error Boundary

  • don’t keep just one error boundary for the entire app
  • wrap around parts of the app to help handle error differently
  • to use error boundary, use the react-error-boundary library
  • it provides functionality which otherwise we might have to write from scratch
  • basic usage - 
    import { ErrorBoundary } from "react-error-boundary";

function ErrorFallback({ error, resetErrorBoundary }) {
  return (
    <div role="alert">
      there was an error - {error.message}
      <button onClick={resetErrorBoundary}>Reset</button>
    </div>
  )
}

// render logic
<ErrorBoundary
  FallbackComponent={ErrorFallback}
  onReset={() => setName("")}
  resetKeys={[name]}
>
  <Info name={name} />
</ErrorBoundary>
  • we provide the fallback component to render, which receives the error and a function resetErrorBoundary which can reset the error inside error boundary back to null
  • however, just resetting the error inside error boundary is not enough, since our app itself is at an erroneous state. this is why we reset the state of our app as well via onReset
  • sometimes, if some state outside the component wrapped by the error boundary changes, it could potentially restore the component back to normal, and we want to reset the error inside error boundary. so, we provide resetKeys. if we did not provide the reset keys, the error fallback would continue to show up despite the changing of name, which could potentially fix the issue

useReducer

  • sometimes decoupling state management from components might result in better code
  • why we should sometimes use objects for maintaining state
  • a basic example - 
    function countReducer(state, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case "INCREMENT":
      return {
        ...state,
        count: state.count + action.step,
      }
    default:
      return state
  }
}

const [{ count }, countDispatch] = React.useReducer(countReducer, {
  count: initialCount,
})

const increment = () =>
  countDispatch({
    type: "INCREMENT",
    step,
  })

Variation I

the use case of writing using the approach above would be when we need a lot of adhoc updates and modelling them via separate scenarios each feels like an overkill. it’s an imperative way of updating state. the reason why we would want a function inside dispatch is the same as setState

const useStateReducer = (reducer, initialState) => {
  const modifiedReducer = (state, action) => {
    return typeof action === "function" ?
      reducer(state, action(state)) :
      reducer(state, action);
  };
  
  const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(modifiedReducer, initialState);

  return [state, dispatch];
};

Variation II

behaves like redux thunk, useful when we want to dispatch multiple actions asynchronously

const useThunkReducer = (reducer, initialState) => {
  const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, initialState);

  const modifiedDispatch = useCallback((action) => {
    typeof action === "function" ? action(dispatch) : dispatch(action);
  }, []);

  return [state, modifiedDispatch];
};

useCallback

  • if we define a function inside a component, the function is created anew every time the component re-renders
  • so, for e.g. if we declared this function inside the dependency list of a useEffect, the callback passed to useEffect would be run on every rerender as well
  • to prevent this, since function is compared by reference, we use useCallback
  • basic usage - useCallback(cb, [deps])
  • simulating useCallback using useMemo - useMemo(() => cb, [deps])

useContext

  • helps share state across components without having to do prop drilling
  • so, a specific part of the tree of our app can have access to the state
  • a common pattern is to write a separate wrapper component for the provider logic
  • basic usage - 
    const CountContext = React.createContext(undefined);

function CountProvider(props) {
  const [count, setCount] = React.useState(0);
  const value = [count, setCount];

  return <CountContext.Provider value={value} children={props.children} />;
}

function useCount() {
  const value = React.useContext(CountContext);
  if (value === undefined) {
    throw new Error("useCount must be used within a CountProvider");
  }

  return value;
}

// render logic
<CountProvider>
  <Counter />
</CountProvider>

// using the context
function CountDisplay() {
  const [count] = useCount();
  return <h1>{count}</h1>;
}
  • we can as a general rule of thumb always memoize the value passed to context 
    const [count, setCount] = React.useState(0);
const value = React.useMemo(() => [count, setCount], [count]);
return <CountContext.Provider value={value} children={children} />;
  • note: in the dependencies list of useEffect, we need not pass dispatch of useReducer, setState of useState, etc

Context Module Functions

  • imagine we are using useReducer inside a context provider
  • generally, we make a function and wrap it with a useCallback
  • we then pass it as one of the values to the context
  • sometimes, a cleaner solution is to make a function which accepts the useReducer’s dispatch
  • the components can then just call that function with the dispatch which comes from the context

Best Practices

  • lifting state - to share state between different components, the state should be on the common parent (ideally the lowest possible common parent). the parent then passes down the state via props
  • colocating state - have the state in the lowest possible component in the tree
  • do not mutate state directly - 
    arr[idx] = newValue // ✖

const copyArr = [...arr] // ✔
copyArr[idx] = newValue
setArr(copyArr)
  • instead of having logic in code like if error, return error related view, if loading, return loading related view etc., maintain a status variable, which can have different values, which determines which view to return. this also removes the need for clearing and resetting different states like loading, error, etc
  • do the setting of status after setting of error / response etc. so that for e.g. react doesn’t try to render the response before it has been set. this problem additionally could have been solved if we maintained our state using an object like in redux and not separately 
    const [error, setError] = useState(null)
const [response, setResponse] = useState(null)
const [status, setStatus] = useState("unset")

// VS

const [data, setData] = useState({
  error: null,
  response: null,
  status: "unset",
})

Control Props

  • think inversion of control
  • the parent component manages the state and not the component itself
  • the goal for the component is to be able to automatically understand based on the props (e.g. if they are undefined) whether it should manage its own state or not
  • e.g. recall how inputs in forms work. they can be controlled i.e. the state is managed by us or we can rely on the state managed by the dom itself

Code Splitting

  • loading code on demand i.e. when the user visits that page
  • also, use network throttling, e.g. set to slow 3g to see the lazy loading in action
  • map.js - 
    import * as React from "react"

function Map() {
  return <div>map</div>
}

export default Map
  • app.js - 
    import * as React from "react"

const Map = React.lazy(() => import("./map"))

function App() {
  return (
    <div>
      <React.Suspense fallback={<div>loading...</div>}>
        <Map />
      </React.Suspense>
    </div>
  )
}
  • eager loading - instead of loading the heavy component when it is asked for, we can load it in parallel to the main application, so that when the user does decide to visit the heavy component, the bundled files are already available to the browser
  • trigger eager loading on some action e.g. before clicking a button - 
    function loadMapLazy() {
  return import("./map")
}

const Map = React.lazy(loadMapLazy)

function App() {
  return (
    // logic for suspense
    <button onFocus={loadMapLazy} onMouseEnter={loadMapLazy}>
      go to maps
    </button>
  )
}
    we can see that technically, the dynamic import statement is being executed multiple times. despite that, webpack will load it only once
  • webpack has a concept of magic comments, using which we can make the default behavior to load in parallel, without triggering it on an action like above - 
    const Map = React.lazy(() => import(/* webpackPrefetch: true */, "./map"));
  • we can also manually suspend the components from the components tab in console to view the fallback. the option is “suspend the selected components”

Custom Hooks

  • they are just like extracting functionality to functions
  • e.g. a custom use local storage hook - 
    const useLocalStorage = (initialState, key) => {
  const [state, setState] = useState(() => {
    const savedState = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem(key));
    if (savedState) return savedState;
    return typeof initialState === "function" ? initialState() : initialState;
  });

  useEffect(() => {
    localStorage.setItem(key, JSON.stringify(state));
  }, [key, state]);

  return [state, setState];
};
